column1: User Account Control prompt dialog box
column2: User Account Control (UAC) Included with Windows Vista and later Microsoft Windows operating systems  UAC prompts the user for authorization when an application tries to perform an administrator task[1]

column1: Runas A commandline tool and contextmenu verb introduced with Windows 2000 that allows running a program  control panel applet  or a MMC snapin as a different user[2] Runas makes use of the "Secondary Login" Windows service  also introduced with Windows 2000[3] This service provides the capability to allow applications running as a separate user to interact with the loggedin user's desktop This is necessary to support draganddrop  clipboard sharing  and other interactive login features
